awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1060940 
Jeffrey Swanson 
Duke University 

This project is a scientific inquiry into the societal problem of violence; the link between mental disorder and risk of violence; and the function of laws designed to reduce that risk. It will provide scientific evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of alternative policies and regulations around violence.

The study will empirically test three theories explaining violence: psychopathological motivation, which attributes violent behavior to features and manifestations of the mental illness; criminogenic risk exposure over the life course, which attributes violent behavior to exposure to social and environmental influences, and social labeling processes, which accounts for the influence of socially-imposed labels about dangerousness. The investigators will analyze administrative data from Connecticut, Massachusetts, and New York. 

The broader impact of this study will be the contribution of new evidence that could contribute to improving policies and regulations and will test the effectiveness of laws that are intended to reduce violence.

Every year in the United States about 118,000 people are injured in gunfire, and about 34,000 of them die. The news media and the public tend to pay special attention to gun violence when there is a horrifying mass shooting by a disturbed young man, and mental illness is then commonly seen as a main cause of the problem. There are urgent calls to improve the mental health care system and to report more gun-prohibiting mental health records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) database in order to reduce gun violence. But does this policy approach work?  Is it fair, in general, to people with mental illnesses? If not, how could the policy be improved, or what might be a more effective and less stigmatizing approach?

Our project studied, for the first time and in a theory-informed way, the time-varying risk of violence and the preventive effect of gun laws in a combined population of over 100,000 people diagnosed with serious mental illnesses over a period of approximately 10 years in Connecticut and Florida (Swanson et al., 2013; Swanson et al., 2016). We matched and merged their mental health, public safety, civil court, criminal justice, and death records.  These laws are intended to protect the public, but may also reinforce the public perception of generalized threat from people with mental illnesses and may in turn perpetuate stigma, marginalization, and unwarranted social control applied to this group.

We found evidence suggesting that serious mental illness is a highly nonspecific risk factor for violent crime, and that other factors were strong and significant predictors of violent crime arrest in multivariable statistical models. Specifically, in Florida we found that arrest for violent crime was rare, but relatively more common than in the general population. However, the annualized arrest rate for gun-involved violent crime in the study population was virtually the same as the estimated general population rate (Swanson et al. 2016). We also examined and compared suicide rates between our study group and the general population. Our Florida study population with serious mental illness was nearly 4 times more likely to die from suicide than adults in the surrounding general population, but less than half as likely to use a firearm in suicide.

We also found that 62% of arrests for violent gun crimes involved suspects who were already legally prohibited from purchasing or possessing a firearm at the time of arrest, yet had obtained a gun anyway. This finding suggests there is a serious problem with implementation and enforcement of gun laws on the books. In contrast, regarding suicide, we found in our Florida study that 72% of gun suicide victims would have been legally eligible to purchase a firearm on the day they used one to end their own life. This suggests a different facet of the problem, i.e., existing legal criteria for prohibiting firearm sales based on a history of involuntary commitment or other mental-health-related adjudication may be too blunt to identify the population at high risk for gun suicide. However, 3 out of 4 of these gun-eligible individuals who completed suicide with a gun were found to have been detained and evaluated in a short-term involuntary psychiatric hold during a previous mental health crisis – without losing their gun rights. This suggests a lost opportunity to limit access to lethal means for an identifiable category of high-risk individuals.

In Connecticut, we studied a comparable population with serious mental illnesses using a similar design. We found a significant 6% reduction in violent crime in gun-disqualified individuals attributable to Connecticut’s initiating a policy of reporting records to NICS in 2007. However, the policy affected only 7% of the study population of persons with serious mental illnesses.  Ninety-six percent of the violent crimes recorded for that population were committed by persons who were not exposed to the policy—i.e., not prohibited from guns by a mental health record. Thus, the estimated net reduction in violent crime attributable to the mental-health-based gun laws per se in Connecticut was minimal (Swanson et al. 2013).

Suggested policy reforms include expanding gun prohibitions to include people with any history of violence or current behavioral indicators of risk, such as people involuntarily detained in short-term psychiatric hospitalizations, and enacting risk-based, preemptive, time-limited gun removal laws.

References

Swanson JW, Easter MM, Robertson AG, Swartz MS, Alanis-Hirsch K, Moseley D, Dion C, Petrila J (2016). Gun violence, mental illness, and laws that prohibit gun possession: evidence from two Florida counties. Health Affairs (Project Hope), 35(6), 1067-1075.

Swanson JW, Robertson AG, Frisman LK, Norko MA, Lin HJ, Swartz MS, Cook PJ (2013). Preventing gun violence involving people with serious mental illness. In Webster DW and Vernick JS, Eds., Reducing Gun Violence in America:  Informing Policy with Evidence and Analysis. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, pp.33-51.
